questions.question: Which of the following pathological conditions involves the accumulation of pigments through exogenous sources?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Coal worker’s pneumoconiosis Explanation: Exogenous pigments Endogenous pigments They originate from external sources and are introduced into the body through environmental exposure or ingestion. They are naturally produced within the body as a result of metabolic processes. E.g. Carbon pigment (exogenous carbon or coal dust) Tattoo ink (skin tattooing) E.g. Melanin Hemosiderin Bilirubin Lipofuscin Porphyrins Homogentisic acid (darkens on exposure to air) Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 76

questions.question: A 83-year-old man presents to his gastroenterologist with complaints of fatigue and discomfort in the upper abdomen. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes medications regularly. On physical examination, the liver edge is palpable below the right costal margin, indicating hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal mildly elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following pigments is most likely responsible for the brown discolouration of the liver observed in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Lipofuscin Explanation: Lipofuscin, also known as lipochrome or wear-and-tear pigment, is an insoluble pigment derived from the peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids in intracellular membranes. It is a telltale sign of free radical injury and lipid peroxidation. It is responsible for the brown atrophy of the liver and heart, where lipofuscin accumulates in the hepatocytes and cardiac myocytes, respectively, due to oxidative damage and impaired cellular turnover, particularly with increasing age. It is also seen in senile atrophy. In histopathological examination, it appears as a yellow-brown, finely granular cytoplasmic pigment, often deposited in the perinuclear region. The special stain used for lipofuscin is Oil red O. Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 76, 77

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with a painless, slow-growing, pigmented lesion on her back with irregular borders and varying shades of brown and black. Excisional biopsy of the lesion is performed, and histopathological examination reveals nests of melanocytes within the dermis, with prominent melanin pigment deposition. Which of the following staining techniques would be most suitable for visualization of the melanin pigment within the melanocytes in this patient's biopsy specimen?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Masson Fontana stain Explanation: Stains for Melanin Masson Fontana Schmorl’s Stain Immunohistochemical stains- Melan-A, HMB-45, S-100 Enzymatic Method- DOPA Oxidase Masson Trichome stain (Option B): Masson Trichrome stain primarily differentiates between collagen and smooth muscle fibres. Periodic-Acid-Schiff (PAS) stain (Option C): Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) stain detects carbohydrates such as glycogen and mucin Immunohistochemical staining for Melan- A (Option D): It is a marker for melanocytes and melanoma cells and is particularly useful in distinguishing melanocytic lesions from other types of skin tumours or metastatic cancers. On the other side, Masson Fontana staining helps to assess the extent of melanin production within tumors.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, joint pain, and abdominal discomfort. On examination, he exhibits bronze-coloured skin pigmentation mainly on the face and hands. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum ferritin levels and transferrin saturation. Which of the following staining techniques would be most appropriate to visualize hemosiderin deposition in tissues in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Perl’s stain Explanation: Perl's stain, also known as Prussian Blue stain is the stain used to detect hemosiderin. The given clinical scenario suggests the patient is suffering from Hemochromatosis, an iron overload disorder in which excessive iron is deposited in various tissues as hemosiderin, a golden yellow to brown, granular, or crystalline pigment. Hemochromatosis can be hereditary or secondary to conditions such as chronic liver disease, frequent blood transfusions, or excessive iron intake. Lillie's stain (Option B): Lillie's stain also known as Lillie-Mayer's hematoxylin-eosin stain might help in detecting Ferrous ions (Fe2+) but is not useful for hemosiderin, which is ferric iron (Fe3+) Rhodanine stain (Option C): Rhodanine is utilized as a selective stain for the detection and localization of copper ions that accumulate in tissues such as the liver and brain in copper metabolism disorders, such as Wilson's disease. Supravital stains (Option D) : Supravital stains are a group of dyes used to stain living cells or tissues without causing cell death. New methylene blue and Brilliant cresyl blue target ribonucleic acid residues in reticulocytes and provide the characteristic blue reticular staining pattern. Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 77

questions.question: Which of the following pathological conditions is associated with the 'Tabby cat' effect?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Diphtheria myocarditis Explanation: Fat accumulation in the heart gives a characteristic Tigroid or Tabby cat appearance, which appears as yellowish streaks (fatty change) alternating with reddish streaks (unaffected myocardium). This appearance is seen in conditions such as Diphtheria myocarditis, Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy (ARVCM), and cell injury. Xanthomas (Option B): Xanthomas are found in skin and in tendons. Cholesterolosis (Option C): Cholesterolosis refers to the cholesterol-laden macrophages in the lamina propria of the gallbladder aka strawberry gallbladder. Fatty liver (Option D): Fatty liver, also known as hepatic steatosis, is characterized by the abnormal accumulation of triglycerides within hepatocytes (liver cells). Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 62, 63

questions.question: Which of the following stains is not typically employed for the detection of lipid accumulation in histological samples?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Toluidine blue Explanation: Stains for fat Oil Red O Sudan Black B Sudan IV Osmium Tetroxide Note: Toluidine Blue is a special stain for Mast cells and Basophils. Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 62, 63

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman presents with bone pain and tenderness over her lower back. Imaging reveals multiple lytic lesions in the vertebral column. Laboratory tests indicate anaemia, elevated serum calcium levels, and monoclonal gammopathy. A bone marrow biopsy confirms plasma cell proliferation. Microscopic examination of the biopsy reveals intracellular inclusions, as shown in the image. What is the composition of the intracellular inclusions marked in the image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Accumulations of immunoglobulins Explanation: The clinical presentation is highly suggestive of multiple myeloma, a plasma cell dyscrasia characterized by bone pain, lytic lesions, anaemia, hypercalcemia, and monoclonal gammopathy. Microscopic examination of the bone marrow biopsy may reveal the presence of intracellular inclusions, such as Russell bodies (Immunoglobulins in the cytoplasm) and Dutcher bodies (containing Ig in the nucleus), within some plasma cells.

questions.question: Following the resection of the pituitary adenoma in a patient with Cushing's disease, which intracellular change is most likely in residual adenoma cells?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Crooke hyaline change Explanation: Crooke hyaline change is a histopathological finding seen in the pituitary gland, particularly in corticotroph adenomas associated with Cushing's disease. In crooke hyaline change, normal granular, basophilic cytoplasm of ACTH-producing cells becomes homogenous and paler due to the accumulation of intermediate keratin filaments. These changes occur as a response to chronic hypercortisolism. Mallory-Denk bodies (Option A): Mallory-Denk bodies or Mallory hyaline bodies are eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions composed of intermediate filaments, particularly cytokeratin 8 and 18, commonly seen in hepatocytes in conditions such as alcoholic liver disease. Conditions where Mallory Hyaline bodies are seen are (Mnemonic: N ew Indian WATCH ) N on-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) Indian childhood cirrhosis W ilson’s disease A lpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency ; A lcoholic Liver Disease T umor of the liver (Hepatocellular carcinoma) Chronic C holestatic conditions H epatic or Primary Biliary cirrhosis (not seen in Secondary biliary cirrhosis) Lewy bodies (Option B): Lewy bodies are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions composed of aggregated alpha-synuclein protein and are characteristic of neurodegenerative disorders such as Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia. Civatte bodies (Option D): They are also known as Colloid Bodies/ Cytoid Bodies and are seen in Lichen Planus.

questions.question: Which of the following stains would be most appropriate for visualizing glycogen deposits?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain Explanation: Glycogen is PAS +ve ; Diastase sensitive Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain (Option A): H&E stain is a basic stain that stains nuclei blue-purple (hematoxylin) and cytoplasm and extracellular matrix pink (eosin). While it can highlight muscle fibre morphology, it does not specifically stain glycogen. Masson's trichrome stain (Option C) : Masson's trichrome stain is used to differentiate collagen fibres (stain blue) from other tissue components. \ It is not specific for visualizing glycogen. Oil Red O stain (Option D): Oil Red O stain is used to detect lipids and fat droplets. Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 64

questions.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect about dystrophic calcification?

options.A: It occurs in damaged or necrotic tissues.
options.B: It is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in normal tissues.
options.C: It is often seen in areas of chronic inflammation.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in normal tissues be a normal blood calcium count. Some examples: Dead Parasite TB Atheroma Monckeberg Sclerosis It is also called calcific medial degeneration. It happens in the tunica media. Calcium occurs blue in color It occurs only as an old age phenomenon without any clinical significance. Psammoma Bodies: It is present as a concentric lamellation. It shows an onion-peel appearance Seen in: Papillary carcinoma of thyroid. Papillary renal cell cancer. meningioma. Prolactinoma Serous Cystadenocarcinoma of ovary. Normal tissues are seen. The blood calcium level is elevated The most common organ affected due to Metastatic calcification - The Lungs Some Examples: Hyperparathyroidism Cancer: RCC and Breast cancer show an increase of calcium. Vitamin D intoxication Milk alkali syndrome Multiple myeloma Sarcoidosis Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 77

questions.question: Which of the following case scenarios is not indicative of metastatic calcification? bilateral lung opacities on chest X-ray. experiencing recurrent kidney stones.

options.A: A 60-year-old male with a history of chronic renal failure presented with shortness of breath and
options.B: A 45-year-old female with spinal tuberculosis complained of back pain.
options.C: A 30-year-old male with a long-standing history of heavy milk and calcium carbonate intake now
options.D: A 55-year-old female with sarcoidosis demonstrated elevated levels of serum vitamin D and calcium.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) A 45-year-old female with spinal tuberculosis complaining of back pain. pain and fractures. Metastatic calcification may occur in normal tissues whenever there is hypercalcemia. There are four principal causes of hypercalcemia: Increased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) with subsequent bone resorption, as in hyperparathyroidism due to parathyroid tumours, and ectopic secretion of PTH-related protein by malignant tumours Resorption of bone tissue, secondary to primary tumours of bone marrow (e.g., multiple myeloma, leukaemia) or diffuse skeletal metastasis (e.g., breast cancer), accelerated bone turnover (e.g., Paget disease), or immobilization. Vitamin D–related disorders, including vitamin D intoxication, sarcoidosis (in which macrophages activate a vitamin D precursor), and idiopathic hypercalcemia of infancy (Williams syndrome), characterized by abnormal sensitivity to vitamin D Renal failure, which causes retention of phosphate, leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism. Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 77

questions.question: Which staining technique is commonly used to visualize calcium deposits in tissues and is particularly useful for detecting minute amounts of calcium?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Alizarin Red S stain Explanation: Stains of Calcium: Von Kossa Stain Imparts black color to calcium. Alizarin Red S Imparts red color to calcium. Used for staining minor amounts of calcium. Calcein IIIIIII Fluorescent stain for calcium Azan Stain IIIIIII To differentiate mineralized bone from osteoid. Masson’s trichrome (Option A): To differentiate collagen and muscle fibers. Prussian blue (Option B): Used for staining Iron. Wright-Giemsa stain (Option D): Used for hematology slides.
